item.description:
I think it would be a lot of fun to see "Forbidden Planet" on the big screen.   Big cheesy old sci fi complete with mad scientist...muahahah!  I am sure I am not the only one.  

The show is at 7:30, but I will be at the theater by 7.  I will have a meetup pin on.

There is a double feature that night so you can also see "The Iron Giant".  I will probably not be staying for the second feature, but since it qualifies as a double feature there, you can see both for the price of one ticket.    The web site doesn't clarify this, but from experience I know you buy the ticket for the first show only. 

To buy tickets go to: 

https://www.vendini.com/ticket-software.html?m=caa188affc9bbaf0886c5c80442eabbc&t=tix&gaOpen=UA-734286-1&gaDone=UA-734286-1

Movie Details:

(1956) dir Fred M. Wilcox w/Leslie Nielsen, Anne Francis, Walter Pidgeon [98 min]
Truly one of the great sci-fi adventures of the 1950s, FORBIDDEN PLANET is a fun, sometimes campy version of Shakespeare’s The Tempest shot into orbit. The magician Prospero here becomes the scientist Dr. Morbius who is isolated on a distant planet with his daughter Altaira. A crew from Earth, lead by the handsome Commander Adams (a pre-comedic Leslie Nielsen), lands on the planet looking for a lost colony and encounters not only the human inhabitants but also Robby The Robot (the film’s version of Ariel) as well as a terrifying unseen monster that threatens them all.

 

The Iron Giant

  • at: 5:30, 9:30 PM

(1999) dir Brad Bird w/Eli Marienthal, Vin Diesel, Harry Connick Jr., Jennifer Aniston [86 min]

Sadly underrated upon its release, Brad Bird (The Incredibles) directed this wonderful sci-fi, coming of age film that wouldn’t be out of place in the Pixar stable – that is if it wasn’t rendered in charming ‘throwback’ traditional cel animation. Set in a Cold War-addled 1950s town, this is the story of a boy and his best friend – a giant robot that falls from the sky one night.
